entry.title: Dockerfile for production
entry.summary: Here we explore how to write a dockerfile for production.
entry.content:
Here we explore how to write a dockerfile for production.

Writing the Dockerfileâ€‹

When creating an image for production, we often don't need the artifacts that were created during the build. Therefor, we can use multitage builds.


#################
# BUILD FOR LOCAL DEVELOPMENT
#################

# Base image for development
FROM node:18-alpine3.15 As development

# Update npm
RUN npm install -g npm

# Create app directory
WORKDIR /usr/src/app

# Install app dependencies
COPY --chown=node:node package*.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install --frozen-lockfile

# Bundle app source
COPY --chown=node:node . .

# Use the node user from the image (instead of the root user)
USER node


#################
# BUILD FOR PRODUCTION
#################

# Base image for building production
FROM node:18-alpine3.15 As build
# ... your build instructions here

# Update npm
RUN npm install -g npm

# Create app directory
WORKDIR /usr/src/app

# Install app dependencies
COPY --chown=node:node package*.json yarn.lock ./
# In order to run `yarn build` we need access to the Nest CLI which is a dev
# dependency. In the previous development stage we ran 
# `yarn install --frozen-lockfile` which installed all dependencies, so we can 
# copy over the node_modules directory from the development image
COPY --chown=node:node --from=development /usr/src/app/node_modules ./node_modules

# Bundle app source
COPY --chown=node:node . .

# Set NODE_ENV environment variable
ENV NODE_ENV production

# Create  a "dist" folder with the production build
RUN yarn build

# Running `yarn install --frozen-lockfile` removes the existing node_modules 
# directory and passing in --only=production ensures that only the production 
# dependencies are installed. This ensures that the node_modules directory is 
# as optimized as possible
RUN rm -rf node_modules && yarn install --frozen-lockfile --only=production

# Use the node user from the image (instead of the root user)
USER node


#################
# PRODUCTION
#################

# Base image for production
FROM node:18-alpine3.15 As production

# Copy the bundled code from the build stage to the production image
COPY --chown=node:node --from=build /usr/src/app/node_modules ./node_modules
COPY --chown=node:node --from=build /usr/src/app/dist ./dist

# Use the node user from the image (instead of the root user)
USER node

# Start the server using the production build
CMD [ "node", "dist/main.js" ]

Building the imageâ€‹

To build the image run:

docker build -t _imageTag_ .

To test locally, you can run:

docker run --rm -p hostPort:containerPort _imageTag_

Now you can visit localhost:hostPort and see your application.

entry.title: Helm
entry.summary: We can define Helm as a package manager for Kubernetes.
entry.content:
We can define Helm as a package manager for Kubernetes.

Installationâ€‹

Depending on you operating system, you might follow different instructions for installing helm. For archlinux you can simply run:

sudo pacman -S helm

Conceptsâ€‹

There are three big basic concepts to Helm:

  • Chart - A Chart contains all the resource definitions necessary to be run the app in Kubernetes.
  • Repository - A Repository is the place where charts live.
  • Release - A Release is an instance of a chart running in a Kubernetes cluster.

With these concepts in mind, we can now explain Helm like this:

Helm installs charts into Kubernetes, creating a new release for each installlation. And to find charts you can install, you can search the Helm chart repositories

Commandsâ€‹

Search chartâ€‹

Helm comes with a powerful search command. It can be used to search two different types of sources:

  • helm search hub searches the Artifact Hub, which lists helm charts from dozens of different repositories.
  • helm search repo searches the repositories that you have added to your local helm client (with `helm repo add).

You can find publicly available charts by runnung helm search hub. For example, to find all wordpress charts on Artifact Hub run:-

helm search hub wordpress

Using helm search repo, you can find the names of the charts in repositories you have already added:

# Add chart to local repository
helm repo add wordpress https://hub.helm.sh/charts/bitnami/wordpress 
# Search for added chart
helm search repo wordpress

Install chartâ€‹

To install a package, use the helm install command. It requires at least two arguments:

  • release name - a name that you pick
  • chart name - the name of the chart you want to install
helm install releaseName bitnami/wordpress

If you want Helm to generate a name for you, swap the releaseName with --generate-name.

To get information about the state of the release, run:

helm status releaseName

Configure chartâ€‹

To see what options are configurable on a chart, use helm show values

helm show values bitnami/wordpress

or, if it is a custom added repo:

helm show values nextcloud --repo https://nextcloud.github.io/helm/

Any of t hese settings can be overwritten in a YAML formatted file, and then passed during installation.

helm install chartName --generate-name -f values.yaml

Uninstall Releaseâ€‹

To uninstalled a release from the Kubernetes Cluster run:

helm uninstall releaseName

To see all deployed releases, run:

helm list

Create chartâ€‹

To get started quickly, run:

helm create chartName

To package the chartm in a .tgz file, run:

helm package chartName

Now you can install the chart using:

helm install releaseName ./chartName-0.1.0.tgz

entry.title: Kubernetes
entry.summary: This guide assumes a basic understanding of containers. In this blog we explore some basic concepts of kubernetes. It is helpful to have template files.
entry.content:
This guide assumes a basic understanding of containers. In this blog we explore some basic concepts of kubernetes. It is helpful to have template files.

Nodesâ€‹

Nodes host applications in form of containers. Nodes can be worker nodes or master nodes.

Master Nodeâ€‹

The control plane in a master node hosts the kube-apiserver which contains:

  • ETCD - a database that stores information in key-value format
  • kube-scheduler - deploys containers to worker nodes
  • controller-manager - monitors and ensures the state of the cluster

Worker Nodeâ€‹

In the worker node the kubelet agent listens to the kube-apiserver and makes sure that the state of the node is as it should by deploying and destroying containers. The kube-proxy service runs on worker nodes and ensures container communication.

Core componentsâ€‹

ETCDâ€‹

When executing a kubectl command the kubeapi-server authenticates and validates requests. It then transacts with the ETCD cluster. You don't have to use kubectl. You can also directly send POST requests to the API. The scheduler monitors the information in ETCD and through the kube-apiserver it instructs the kubelet in the worker nodes to create or destroy pods. The kubelet daemon reports to the kube-apiserver which transacts the information with ETCD.

kube-spiserverâ€‹

The kube-apiserver is deployed as a pod within the kube-system namespace in the master node . To view the pods within the kube-system namespace, run:

kubectl get pods -n kube-system

You can see the options within the pod definition file locatet at:

cat /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-apiserver

You can view the systemd kube-apiserve service definition by running:

cat /etc/systemd/system/kube-apiserver.service

You can also see the running procces:

ps -aus | grep kube-apiserver

kube-controller-managerâ€‹

Ensures the correct state of the kubernetes cluster. It is a process that continiously monitors the state of various components and takes neccesary actions to ensure the correct state. For example, the node-controller checks the status of the nodes through the kube-apiserver every 5 seconds. If it doesn't recieve heartbeats from the node, it marks it unreachable. THe node has then 5 minutes to come back up. If it doesn't, it removes the pods from that node and rechedules them on healthy nodes.

kube-controller-manager is also deployed as a pod within the kube-system namespace:

kubectl get pods -n kube-system

You can view the kube-controller-manager options in the manifest folder:

cat /etc/kubernetes/manifests/kube-controller-manager.yaml

kube-schedulerâ€‹

The kube-scheduler only decides which pods go to which node. It doesn't actually place the pod on the node. That is the job of the kubelet which runs on each node. Depending on pods' resource requirements the scheduler finds the best nodes for them. It uses a score system to achieve that. Some of the criteria are:

  • Resource requirements and limits
  • taints and tolerations
  • node selectors/affinity

kubeletâ€‹

The kubelet manages the whole worker node.

kube-proxyâ€‹

kube-procy is a process that runs on each node in the kubernetes cluster. It looks for services and creates the rules for forwarding traefic that targets a service to the corresponding pods. It achieves this by using ip-tables rules. It translates the IP of the service to the IP of the matching pod. A service is a virtual component, it doesn't run any application by itself.

Objectsâ€‹

Podâ€‹

A pod is a single instance of the application. Pods have containers. For scaling you replicate the pods, not the containers within a pod!

Deploying a podâ€‹

To deploy a pod, you can for example run:

kubectl run nginx --image nginx

To see the pod, you can run kubectl get pods.

Pods with yamlâ€‹

Kubernetes can use yaml files for creation of objects such as pods, replicas, deployments, services, etc. They all follow a similar structure:

# pod.yaml
apiVersionL: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: podName
  labels:
    podLabel: podLabelValue
    anotherPodLabel: anotherPodLabelValue
spec:
  containers:
    - name: containerName
      image: containerImage
apiVersionâ€‹

The apiVersion is the version of the kubernetes api you are using to create the object. A few possible values are:

KindVersion
Podv1
Servicev1
ReplicaSetapps/v1
Deploymentapps/v1
kindâ€‹

The kind refers to the type of object we want to create. Some possible values are: Pod, Service, ReplicaSet and Deployment.

metadataâ€‹

The metadata is data about the object like its name and labels.

specâ€‹

The spec provides additional information about the object. It is specific to each kind.

Once the definition file is created run the following command to create the pod (assuming you named the definition file pod.yaml):

kubectl create -f pod.yaml

For detailed information about the pod, run:

kubectl describe pod podName

ReplicaSetâ€‹

The ReplicaSet helps us run more than one instance of the same Pod, thus providing high availability. By using a ReplicaSet we can balance the load across multiple pods which can run across worker nodes.

ReplicaSet with yamlâ€‹

# ReplicaSet.yaml
apiVersion: /apps/v1
kind: ReplicaSet
metadata:
  name: replicaSetName
  labels:
    replicaSetLabel: replicaSetLabelValue
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      name: podName
      labels:
        podLabel: podLabelValue
        anotherPodLabel: anotherPodLabelValue
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: containerName
          image: containerImage
replicas: 2
selector:
  matchLabels:
    podLabel: podLabelValue
templateâ€‹

The template is the Pod definition without the fields apiVersion and kind.

replicasâ€‹

The number of pods that should be running.

selectorâ€‹

The selector identifies the Pods the ReplicaSet should manage. It does so, by matching the labels.

When ready, run the following command to create the ReplicaSet:

kubectl create -f ReplicaSet.yaml

Similar to the pods, you can run kubectl comands to inspect other objects such as the ReplicaSet.

kubectl get replicaset

Scale ReplicaSetâ€‹

To scale the ReplicaSet, that is to change the target number of running pods, first change the number of replicas in the ReplicaSet definition file. Then, run the following command:

kubectl replace -f ReplicaSet.yaml

Another way to do it is to use the same definition file, but run kubectl scale instead.

kubectl scale --replicas=6 -f ReplicaSet.yaml

or

kubectl scale --replicas=6 replicaset replicaSetName

The second method will not modify the file.

tip

Don't forget to run kubectl --help for helpful information!

Deploymentsâ€‹

A Deployments offers extra capabilities to a ReplicaSet that allows for seamless version swtiching.

Deployment definition file.â€‹

The Deployment definition file is similar to the Replicaset definition file.

# ReplicaSet.yaml
apiVersion: /apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: replicaSetName
  labels:
    replicaSetLabel: replicaSetLabelValue
spec:
  template:
    metadata:
      name: podName
      labels:
        podLabel: podLabelValue
        anotherPodLabel: anotherPodLabelValue
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: containerName
          image: containerImage
replicas: 2
selector:
  matchLabels:
    podLabel: podLabelValue

Similar to other objects, kubectl commands are also available for deployments.

Namespacesâ€‹

Namescpaces provide isolation. Cubernetes creates a set of pods and services for its internal purposes under the namespace called kube-system. Each namespace can have its own set of policies.Resouce limits can also be assigned to namespaces.

Connect to services across namespacesâ€‹

Within a namespace, you can reach a service simply by its name. To target a service from another namespace dev append .dev.svc.cluster.local to the service name.

kubectl with namespacesâ€‹

To target a specific namespace, append it to the kubectl commmand after --namespace= argument. Note, this also works to determine in which namespace an object should be created.

yaml definition namespaceâ€‹

If you specify a namespace: under the metadata section in the definition file, by default the object will be created under that namespace.

How to create a new namespace?â€‹

Like for any other object, you can use a namespace definition file,

## Namespace.yaml
apiVersionL v1
kind: Namespace
metadata:
  name: namespaceName

or by running:

kubectl create namespace namespaceName

Switch namespaceâ€‹

To set a namespace as default for kubectl commands use:

kubectl config set-context $(kubectl config current-context) --namespace=namespaceName

Resource Quotaâ€‹

To define resource limitations within a namespace, use a Resource Quota. To create a Resource Quota, you can use a definition file.

# ResourceQuota.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ResourceQuota
metadata:
  name: resourceQuotaName
  namespace: namespaceName
spec:
  hard:
    pods: "numberOfPods"
    requests.cpu: "numberOfCpus"
    requests.memory: "valueOfMemory"
    limits.cpu: "numberOfCpus"
    limit.memory: "valueOfMaxMemory"

Servicesâ€‹

Services enable the connection between groups of pods.

NodePortâ€‹

A NodePort Service maps a port on the node to a port on the Pod. The TargetPort is the port on the Pod. The port on the Service itself is refered to as the Port. The Service has its own IP address within the cluster called Service ClusterIP. The Port on the Node itself is called NodePort. The default valid range for NodePorts is 30000-32767

NodePort Service yaml fileâ€‹

THe definition file for the NodePort Service looks like this:

# NodePortService.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: serviceName
spec:
  type: NodePort
  ports:
    - targetPort: 80
      port: 80
      nodePort: 30003
  selector:
    podLabel: podLabelValue

Within the ports array, only the port is mandatory. targetPort will be assumed to be same as Port and nodePort will be chosen at random within the valid range. To link the service to a Pod, use labels with selectors.

ClusterIPâ€‹

A ClusterIP Service is a service that is only accesible within a cluster using its ClusterIP or the service name.

ClusterIP yaml fileâ€‹

# NodePortService.yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: serviceName
spec:
  type: ClusterIP
  ports:
    - targetPort: 80
      port: 80
  selector:
    podLabel: podLabelValue

Schedulingâ€‹

Every Pod has a filed called nodeName that is not set by default. The scheduler schedules a pod on a node by setting the nodeName property of the Pod to the name of the node. For scheduling a pod manualy, you can set the nodeName yourself.

Binding object.â€‹

To reschedule a pod to another node, write a binding definition.

apiVersion: v1
kind: Binding
metadata:
  name: nginx
target:
  apiVersion: 1
  kind: Node
  name: nodeName

Then, send a post requist to the binding API.

curl --header "Context-Type:application/json" --request POST --data '{"apiVersion":"v1", "kind":"Binding"...' http://$SERVER/api/v1/namespaces/default/pods/$PODNAME/binding

Tainsâ€‹

Toleranceâ€‹

Node Selectorsâ€‹

Node Affinityâ€‹

DaemonSetsâ€‹

Metrics serviceâ€‹

Cluster performance can be viewed by running

kubectl top node

To log events in a pod use:

kubectl logs -f podName

Networkingâ€‹

Traefik Ingressâ€‹

A trafik ingress definition file looks like this:â€‹

apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  name: IngressName
  namespace: default

spec:
  rules:
    - host: example.com
      http:
        paths:
          - path: /
            pathType: Exact
            backend:
              service:
                name:  serviceName
                port:
                  number: 80

Storageâ€‹

Local Storage Provider.â€‹

A Local Storage Provider enabled the ability to create persistent volume claims using local storage on the node.

Persistent Volume Claimâ€‹

apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: persistentVolumeClaimName
  namespace: default
spec:
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  storageClassName: local-path
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 2Gi

Pod with local storageâ€‹

apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  name: podName
  namespace: default
spec:
  containers:
    - image:imageName
      name: containerName
      imagePullPolicy: IfNotPresent
      volumeMounts:
        - name: volumeName 
          mountPath: pathOnTheContainer
      ports:
        - containerPort: portNumber
  volumes:
    - name: volumeName
      persistentVolumeClaim:
        claimName: persistentVolumeClaimName

Then, you can apply the yaml using kubectl.

entry.title: Linux Tricks
entry.summary: Here we document some handy linux tips and tricks.
entry.content:
Here we document some handy linux tips and tricks.

Command aliasesâ€‹

Create .bash_aliases in your home directory.

touch ~/.bash_aliases

Write the following inside .bash_aliases:

# ~/.bash_aliases
alias l='ls -lah'

Now source .bash_aliases from inside .bashrc.

# ~/.bashrc
...
source ~/.bash_aliases

Restart terminal. Now you can use l instead of ls -lah.

entry.title: Install custom image on Contabo
entry.summary: How to install a custom Arch Image on Contabo.
entry.content:
How to install a custom Arch Image on Contabo.

Choose Custom installationâ€‹

Disable cloud-init

Choose custom install

Now use a VNC client with the provided credentials from contabo. Then choose your image. Here I chose Arch Linux.

Do a ping test:

ping google.com

Create Partitionsâ€‹

Create an empty GPT partition table. Use m for a list of avalable commands.

fdisk /dev/sda

Create a bios_grub partiton of 1MiB starting at 1MiB from the start of the disk.

n
2048
+1MiB

Set type as bios_grub.

t
4

Now create the root partition with the size of 30GiB:

n
2
4096
+30GiB

Create other partitions you might need, for example home.

Format partitions with a ext4 filesystem:

mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sda2

Mount root partition in /mnt directory. In case you craeted a home partition, mount it to /mnt/home

mount /dev/sda2 /mnt
mount -o x-mount.mkdir /dev/sda4 /mnt/home

Install base system:

pacstrap -i /mnt base linux linux-firmware

Configure fstab for the new installation.

genfstab -U /mnt >> /mnt/etc/fstab

Chrootâ€‹

Change root into the new system. Then install a text editor.

arch-chroot /mnt
pacman -S nano

Set timezone:

ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/Region/City /etc/localtime

Edit /etc/locale.gen by uncommenting en_US.UTF-8 UTF-8. Generate the locales.

nano /etc/locale.gen
locale-gen

Create a locale.conf file, and set the LANG variable accordingly.

# /etc/locale.conf
LANG=en_US.UTF-8

Important! Don't forget to setup a root password!

passwd

Install bootloader.

pacman -S grub
grub-install /dev/sda --target=i386-pc
grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg

Reboot and good luck ðŸ¤ž.

Configuring networkâ€‹

To use systemd-networkd, enable the service. When reconiguring, restart service.

systemctl enable --now systemd-networkd

Check network device name using ip a.

Wired adapter using DHCPâ€‹

# /etc/systemd/network/20-wired.network
[Match]
Name=YOUR_NETWORK_DEVICE_NAME

[Network]
DHCP=yes
DNS=8.8.8.8

Wired adapter using a static IPâ€‹

# /etc/systemd/network/20-wired.network
[Match]
Name=YOUR_NETWORK_DEVICE_NAME

[Network]
Address=YOUR_STATIC_IP_ADDRESS
Gateway=YOUR_GATEWAY
DNS=8.8.8.8
systemctl enable --now systemd-networkd

Install sudoâ€‹

pacman -S sudo

Create a new user.

useradd --create-home YOUR_USERNAME
usermod --append --groups wheel

Edit sudoes file to uncommen wheel user.

EDITOR=nano visudo

# Then find and uncomment
%wheel ALL=(ALL:ALL) NOPASSWD:ALL

# Then login to user and test
su YOUR_USERNAME
sudo echo hello

Enable SSHâ€‹

sudo pacman -S openssh
sudo systemctl enable --now sshd

Generate SSH keys on client and server.

ssh-keygen -t ed25519

Copy the content of the public key of the client and paste it to the file ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on the server.

Force public key authentication

# /etc/ssh/sshd_config
PasswordAuthentication no
AuthenticationMethods publickey

entry.title: Redux Toolkit Template
entry.summary: Redux toolkit (RTK) offers a great solution for state management and caching data. Let's get started!
entry.content:
Redux toolkit (RTK) offers a great solution for state management and caching data. Let's get started!

Create a new projectâ€‹

Follow the prompts. Use react and typescript.

yarn create vite

Install dependencies:

yarn i @reduxjs/toolkit react-redux axios

Create redux sliceâ€‹

Create a folder named counter

mkdir ./src/features/counter

Inside the counter folder, create a file named counterSlice.ts. It should have the following content.

// counterSlice.ts

import { createSlice, PayloadAction } from '@reduxjs/toolkit'

interface CounterState {
  value: number
}

const initialState: CounterState = {
  value: 0
}

const counterSlice = createSlice({
  name: 'counter',
  initialState,
  reducers: {
    incremented(state) {
      state.value++;
    },
      amountAdded(state, action: PayloadAction<number>) {
      state.value += action.payload
    }
  }
});


export const { incremented, amountAdded } = counterSlice.actions
export default counterSlice.reducer

Configure redux storeâ€‹

Make a new folder called app

mkdir ./src/app

Inside the app folder, create a file named store.ts. It should have the following content:

import { configureStore } from "@reduxjs/toolkit";
import counterReducer from '../features/counter/counterSlice'

export const store = configureStore({
  reducer: {
    counter: counterReducer
  }
})

export type AppDispatch = typeof store.dispatch;
export type RootState = ReturnType<typeof store.getState>;

Setup the redux react provider so the application can access the store. Inside the main.ts file, make adjustments:

import { Provider } from 'react-redux'
import { store } from './app/store'
...
  <Provider store={store}>
    <App />
  </Provider>
...

Inside the ./src/app folder, let's make a file called hooks.ts. It should have the following content:

import { TypedUseSelectorHook, useDispatch, useSelector } from 'react-redux'
import { RootState, AppDispatch } from './store'

export const useAppDispatch = () => useDispatch<AppDispatch>()
export const useAppSelector: TypedUseSelectorHook<RootState> = useSelector;

Using the storeâ€‹

Inside App.ts, import those hooks and the incremented action creator:

import { useAppDispatch, useAppSelector } from './app/hooks'
import { incremented } from './features/counter/counterSlice'

Now read the count value using:

const count = useAppSelector((state) => state.counter.value)

Dispatch action using: 

const dispatch = useAppDispatch()
...
  // onClick={() => dispatch(incremented())}
  onClick={() => dispatch(amountAdded(5))}
...

Using RTK Queryâ€‹

Inside the ./src/feature/dogs/ folder, create a file named dogsApiSlice.ts. It should have the following content:

import { createApi, fetchBaseQuery } from '@reduxjs/toolkit/query/react'

const DOGS_API_KEY = 'your_dog_api_key_here'

interface Breed {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  image: {
    url: string;
  }
}

export const dogsApiSlice = createApi({
  reducerPath: 'api',
  baseQuery: fetchBaseQuery({
    baseUrl: 'https://api.thedogapi.com/v1',
    prepareHeaders(headers) {
      headers.set('x-api-key', DOGS_API_KEY);
      return headers
    }
  }),
  endpoints(builder) {
    return {
      fetchBreeds: builder.query<Breed[], number | void>({
        query(limit = 10) {
          return `/breeds?limit=${limit}`
        }
      })
    }
  }
})

export const { useFetchBreedsQuery } = dogsApiSlice

Let's go back to our store.ts file. After importing, adding the reducer and the middleware, it should look like this:

import { configureStore } from "@reduxjs/toolkit";
import counterReducer from '../features/counter/counterSlice'
import { dogsApiSlice } from "../features/dogs/dogsApiSlice";

export const store = configureStore({
  reducer: {
    counter: counterReducer,
    [dogsApiSlice.reducerPath]: dogsApiSlice.reducer
  },
  middleware: (getDefaultMiddleware) => {
    return getDefaultMiddleware().concat(dogsApiSlice.middleware)
  }
})

export type AppDispatch = typeof store.dispatch;
export type RootState = ReturnType<typeof store.getState>;

Now, to fetch, go to App.ts.

import { useFetchBreedsQuery } from './features/dogs/dogsApiSlice'

function App() {
  const { data = [], isFetching } = useFetchBreedsQuery();
  ...
}

entry.title: Vite Import Alias
entry.summary: Under vite.config.ts, inside the defineConfig object, add:
entry.content:
Under vite.config.ts, inside the defineConfig object, add:

defineConfig: {
  resolve: {
    alias: {
      '@': path.resolve(__dirname, './src')
    }
  }
}

Then, under tsconfig.json, inside the compilerOptions object, add:

"compilerOptions": {
  "paths": {
    "@/*": ["./src/*"]
  }
}

Now, instead of ../../../component, you can simply use @/component.

entry.title: Kubernetes Nginx Ingress
entry.summary: After bootstrapping Kubernetes using kubeadm and learning some Kubernetes primitives, we start to learn about an ingress controller. For convenience, we will use Helm as our package manager for Kubernetes.
entry.content:
After bootstrapping Kubernetes using kubeadm and learning some Kubernetes primitives, we start to learn about an ingress controller. For convenience, we will use Helm as our package manager for Kubernetes.

Installing a container runnerâ€‹

Let's make sure we have a container runner installed and the service running. For Arch Linux:

Install CRI-O:

sudo pacman -Syu cri-o

Enable the CRI-O service:

sudo systemctl enable --now crio

Bootstrapping Kubernetes using kubeadmâ€‹

Now we can bootstrap our Kubernetes installation by running:

sudo kubeadm init --pod-network-cidr=192.168.0.0/16

To be able to run kubectl from current user use:

mkdir -p $HOME/.kube
sudo cp -i /etc/kubernetes/admin.conf $HOME/.kube/config
sudo chown $(id -u):$(id -g) $HOME/.kube/config

Now install Calico:

  1. Install the Tigera Calico operator and custom resource definitions.
kubectl create -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/projectcalico/calico/v3.24.3/manifests/tigera-operator.yaml
  1. Install Calico by creating the necessary custom resource:
kubectl create -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/projectcalico/calico/v3.24.3/manifests/custom-resources.yaml

Verify that all system pods are running:

kubectl get pods --all-namespaces

By default, new pods will not be scheduled on the control plane node. You can change that by running:

kubectl taint nodes --all node-role.kubernetes.io/control-plane-

Using Helmâ€‹

To install helm use:

sudo pacman -S helm

To allow referencing to localhost via ipv6, modify /etc/systemd/resolved.conf to include:

# /etc/systemd/resolved.conf
DNSStubListenerExtra=[::1]:53

Add nginx repo by running:

helm repo add ingress-nginx https://kubernetes.github.io/ingress-nginx=

Now update helm repo:

helm repo update

To view chart configuration values run:

helm show values ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx

To install the chart run:

helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx

entry.title: Minikube
entry.summary: Kubernetes is a enterprise application and is designed to run across multiple machines. Each machine is called a node.
entry.content:
Kubernetes is a enterprise application and is designed to run across multiple machines. Each machine is called a node.

Setting up a learning environmentâ€‹

When learning, we might have only one machine available. In that case we can create a single node setup using minikube. Here we assume we already know basics of docker. Continue buy installing minikube following the documentation for your specific OS. In ArchLinux type:

sudo pacman -Sy minikube

To start a single node cluster run:

minikube start

Select docker as the execution engine. VMs are also an option, but consume more resources. You can check the newly created cluster using:

minikube status

To stop the cluster run:

minikube stop

Visit the documentation for more minikube commands.

Interact with your clusterâ€‹

If you already have kubectl installed, you can now use it to access your shiny new cluster:

kubectl get po -A

entry.title: Angular in Docker
entry.summary: Angular not always supports the latest node.js version. Docker can help keep our system clean.
entry.content:
Angular not always supports the latest node.js version. Docker can help keep our system clean.

Create node userâ€‹

For best practice, create node user and append node group to current user.

sudo useradd node
sudo usermod --append --groups node $USER

Build Angular image:â€‹

Use the node version Angular supports. At the time of this writing it is version 14.

FROM node:14-alpine
RUN npm install -g @angular/cli
USER node
WORKDIR /app
EXPOSE 4200 49153
CMD npm start

Build the image. In this example it is tagged ng:

docker build --tag ng .

Using the Angular CLI within Dockerâ€‹

Run the development container:

docker run -it -v $(pwd):/app -p 4200:4200 -p 49153:49153 --name ng ng sh

Create a new project:

ng new --skip-git

Adjust start script in package.json to:

 start": "ng serve --host 0.0.0.0 --poll"

Otherwise the port would not be accessible from outside the container.

entry.title: Make RAID0 array using MDADM
entry.summary: Sometimes you need RAID0 for increased capacity and speed.
entry.content:
Sometimes you need RAID0 for increased capacity and speed.

Load needed modulesâ€‹

Start with loading the raid0 kernel module:

modprobe raid0

Add it to /etc/modules-load.d so it gets loaded during next reboot:

echo raid0 >> /etc/modules-load.d/raid0.conf

Assemble existing arrayâ€‹

Find UUID of target array:

blkid

Assemble using mdadm:

mdadm --assemble /dev/md0 --uuid <array_uuid>

Make persistant on Alpine:â€‹

Create the /etc/mdadm.conf file so mdadm knows how your RAID is set up:

mdadm --detail --scan > /etc/mdadm.conf

To make sure the raid devices start during the next reboot run:

rc-update add mdadm-raid

To use the raid array in /etc/fstab at boot, the mdadm service must be started at boot time:

rc-update add mdadm boot
rc-update add mdadm-raid boot

Finally, to persist changes in /etc directory, run (Alpine only!):

lbu ci

entry.title: Scaffolding React App
entry.summary: React is a library it doesn't care about project structure. You have to manage it instead.
entry.content:
React is a library it doesn't care about project structure. You have to manage it instead.

Scaffolding using vite:

pnpm create vite

Then follow the prompts!

tip

Check out Awesome Vite for community maintained templates that include other tools or target different frameworks. You can use a tool like degit to scaffold your project with the Vitamin template.

npx degit wtchnm/Vitamin#main my-app
cd my-project

pnpm install
pnpm run dev

entry.title: Welcome
entry.summary: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
entry.content:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
